title: Manam Volcano
meta_title: Manam Volcano — PNG's Most Active, Eruption History & Facts | VolcanoAtlas
meta_description: Manam is a 1,807 m stratovolcano and one of Papua New Guinea's most active volcanoes, with 46 eruptions since 1616 including devastating events in 2004 and 2018.

quick_answer.what: Manam is a 1,807 m (5,928 ft) active stratovolcano forming a 10-km-wide island 13 km off the northern coast of mainland Papua New Guinea, and one of the country's most active and dangerous volcanoes.
quick_answer.status: Active — currently erupting (2018-present). Multiple VEI 4 eruptions in recent decades. Monitored by RVO.
quick_answer.famous_for: Repeated devastating eruptions forcing complete island evacuations, four radial valleys channeling pyroclastic flows to the coast, and its status as PNG's most persistently active volcano.
quick_answer.danger_level: Very high — approximately 10,000 people live on the island. Eruptions in 2004 and 2018 forced complete island evacuations.

overview.content: Manam is an active basaltic-andesitic stratovolcano forming a roughly circular, 10-km-wide island located 13 km off the northern coast of mainland Papua New Guinea in the Bismarck Sea, Madang Province. Rising to 1,807 m (5,928 ft) from the seafloor, it is one of the country's most active and most dangerous volcanoes, with 46 recorded eruptions since 1616 and a persistent pattern of activity that has made life on the island both vibrant and perilous for its approximately 10,000 inhabitants. Manam is part of the Bismarck Volcanic Arc, generated by complex subduction dynamics where the Pacific and Solomon Sea plates interact with the Bismarck microplate. The volcano's conical form is divided into four large radial valleys extending from the unvegetated summit to the coast. These valleys — oriented roughly to the northeast, southeast, southwest, and northwest — channel lava flows and pyroclastic avalanches, concentrating volcanic hazards along their paths and periodically directing destructive flows into populated coastal villages. Two summit craters, the Main (northern) and Southern craters, are both active, though the Southern crater has produced most observed eruptions over the past century. Eruptions range from mild Strombolian activity to violent VEI 4 paroxysms generating pyroclastic flows that reach the sea. The most devastating recent eruptions — in 1996, 2004, 2014, and 2018 — killed residents, destroyed villages, and forced complete island evacuations. Despite repeated evacuations, many islanders return because Manam is their ancestral homeland and the volcanic soils support productive agriculture. Manam is monitored by the Rabaul Volcanological Observatory (RVO), which operates seismic stations on the island and coordinates with the Darwin Volcanic Ash Advisory Centre for aviation warnings.

geology_and_formation.content: Manam is a submarine stratovolcano whose summit emerges 1,807 m above sea level from the Bismarck Sea floor. The total edifice height, measured from the surrounding seafloor, is approximately 4,000 m, making the submarine portion far larger than the visible island. The volcano is built primarily from basaltic to basaltic-andesitic lavas and pyroclastic deposits, typical of arc volcanism in the western Pacific. The Bismarck Volcanic Arc results from the subduction of the Solomon Sea Plate beneath the South Bismarck Plate along the New Britain Trench system. This complex tectonic environment — involving microplate interactions, back-arc spreading, and multiple subduction zones — produces a chain of highly active volcanoes across Papua New Guinea, including Manam, Langila, Ulawun, and Rabaul. Manam sits at the northwestern end of this arc. The four large radial valleys that divide the island into quadrants are erosional and structural features that fundamentally control hazard distribution. These valleys extend from the summit zone to the coast and are partially filled with deposits from centuries of eruptions. During eruptions, they channel fast-moving volcanic material directly toward the coastal lowlands where most of the island's population lives. Five small satellite volcanic centers near the island's shoreline on the northern, southern, and western sides represent secondary vents. The volcano's basaltic to basaltic-andesitic composition enables both relatively fluid lava flows and, during paroxysmal events, violently explosive activity driven by rapid magma ascent and degassing.

eruption_history_overview.content:
Manam's recorded eruption history begins in 1616 with the first European observation and includes 46 documented eruptions — an average of roughly one eruption every 8-9 years, though activity is often semi-continuous. The volcano has been particularly active since the early 20th century, with eruptions in most decades from the 1900s onward. Activity predominantly originates from the Southern crater, which has been the main eruptive vent for much of the past century, channeling products primarily through the southeast valley.

Eruption intensities range from persistent low-level Strombolian activity (VEI 1-2) to violent paroxysmal eruptions (VEI 3-4) generating pyroclastic flows, heavy tephra fall, and lava flows reaching the coast. Four eruptions have reached VEI 4: the 1919 event, and three 21st-century events in 2004, 2014, and 2018. The frequency and intensity of major eruptions appear to have increased in recent decades, raising significant concern for the island's population and prompting ongoing scientific study and humanitarian planning.

subsections.title: The 1919 Eruption — VEI 4, First Major Documented Paroxysm
subsections.content: The 1919 eruption was the first well-documented major eruption of Manam, reaching VEI 4 and producing powerful explosions from both the Southern and Main craters. Pyroclastic flows swept down the radial valleys to the coast, and heavy tephra fall blanketed the island. At least one fatality was recorded. The eruption caused significant destruction to villages and gardens, prompting the first formal discussions about the danger posed by the volcano. The 1919 event established the pattern of violent paroxysmal eruptions that has defined Manam's modern behavior and provided a baseline for assessing future eruption scenarios.

subsections.title: The 1996 Eruption — Deadly Pyroclastic Flows
subsections.content: In November 1996, a powerful eruption generated pyroclastic flows that swept through the southwest valley and reached coastal villages, killing 13 people. The eruption began with vigorous Strombolian activity that rapidly escalated to violent explosions. The pyroclastic flows — fast-moving currents of hot gas and rock exceeding 300 degrees Celsius and speeds above 100 km/h — gave residents in the valley path virtually no time to flee. The 1996 disaster highlighted the extreme vulnerability of communities living within the radial valley paths and brought international attention to Manam's volcanic hazard. It also demonstrated a critical limitation: even with monitoring, the transition from background activity to lethal paroxysm can occur too rapidly for effective warning and evacuation.

subsections.title: The 2004 Eruption — Complete Island Evacuation
subsections.content:
The most destructive eruption in Manam's modern history began in October 2004, reaching VEI 4 with powerful explosions that sent pyroclastic flows down the southeast and southwest valleys to the coast. Lava flows also reached the sea. At least 5 people were killed and villages along the valley paths were destroyed. For the first time, the entire population of the island — approximately 10,000 people — was evacuated to the mainland by boat and aircraft in a major humanitarian operation coordinated by the PNG government and international aid organizations.

The evacuation created a long-running displacement crisis. Evacuees were resettled in temporary camps near Bogia on the mainland coast, where conditions were often poor and tensions with local host communities arose over land and resources. Despite government warnings against returning, many Manam islanders gradually drifted back to their homes over subsequent years, driven by attachment to ancestral land, inadequate resettlement options, and the productivity of volcanic soils. This pattern of eruption, evacuation, failed resettlement, and return has become the defining humanitarian challenge of Manam's volcanic risk.

subsections.title: The 2018-Present Eruption — Ongoing Crisis
subsections.content:
Manam entered another period of intense activity in 2018 with VEI 4 eruptions producing powerful explosions in June and August that generated pyroclastic flows down the southeast valley and ash columns reaching 15,000+ m altitude. Approximately 2,000 people were evacuated from coastal villages in the direct path of flows. Activity continued intermittently through 2025, with VEI 3 explosions, persistent Strombolian activity, and intermittent lava flows from the Southern crater. Satellite monitoring has detected persistent SO2 plumes and thermal anomalies.

The ongoing activity reinforces Manam's status as one of the most persistently dangerous volcanoes in the southwestern Pacific. International disaster response organizations including the International Federation of Red Cross, UNICEF, and various NGOs have provided support during successive evacuations, but the fundamental problem — a large population living on a highly active volcanic island with no viable permanent relocation alternative — remains unresolved.

current_status_and_monitoring.content:
Manam has been in a state of semi-continuous eruption since 2018, with activity concentrated at the Southern crater. Current activity typically consists of Strombolian explosions, ash venting, and intermittent lava flows channeled through the southeast valley. Occasional larger explosions produce ash columns reaching 5,000-10,000 m altitude and trigger aviation alerts for the Bismarck Sea region.

The Rabaul Volcanological Observatory (RVO) operates seismic monitoring stations on the island and coordinates with the Darwin Volcanic Ash Advisory Centre (VAAC) for aviation warnings. Monitoring capabilities are more limited than at volcanoes in wealthier nations — the seismic network is relatively sparse, real-time gas monitoring is intermittent, and infrastructure is vulnerable to eruption damage. International collaborations with Australian, Japanese, and European research institutions supplement monitoring with satellite observations, campaign gas measurements, and hazard modeling. Scientists assess that Manam will continue to erupt for the foreseeable future, with the potential for VEI 4 paroxysms remaining a persistent threat to the island population.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Manam presents an acute volcanic hazard directly compounded by population exposure. Approximately 10,000 people live on the island, with villages concentrated along coastal lowlands — precisely where the four radial valleys deliver pyroclastic flows, lava, and lahars. There is no part of the island's lowlands entirely safe from all hazard types during a major eruption. The primary lethal hazard is pyroclastic flows and surges channeled down radial valleys at speeds exceeding 100 km/h, reaching the coast in minutes and providing essentially zero warning time. The 1996 eruption demonstrated this: 13 people died because there was no time to escape. Secondary hazards include heavy tephra fall (collapsing roofs, contaminating water, destroying crops), lava flows, ballistic projectiles, and volcanic gas. The fundamental challenge is not scientific — hazards are well-characterized — but the absence of viable permanent relocation. The island's population has deep cultural and economic ties to Manam, and mainland resettlement has repeatedly failed. This creates a cycle of eruption, evacuation, inadequate resettlement, and return. Compared to other volcanic islands such as Stromboli (Italy, ~500 residents, well-monitored) or Montserrat (UK territory, southern half permanently evacuated after 1995), Manam's combination of high population, high eruption frequency, VEI 4 capability, and limited monitoring and evacuation infrastructure makes it among the most hazardous volcano-population pairings in the world.

geography_and_physical_description.content:
Manam island is roughly circular, approximately 10 km in diameter, rising steeply from the Bismarck Sea to its 1,807 m summit. It lies 13 km off the mainland coast near Bogia, Madang Province. The volcanic cone is dissected by four large radial valleys oriented to the northeast, southeast, southwest, and northwest, giving the island a distinctive quadrant-divided appearance from the air.

The summit zone is barren, dominated by the two active craters — Main (northern) and Southern — separated by a narrow ridge. Below the summit, slopes transition through alpine scrub, montane forest, and productive tropical gardens and coconut plantations on the lower slopes and coastal flats. The southeast valley has received the heaviest accumulation from recent eruptions. Five small satellite cones near the shoreline represent secondary volcanic centers. The narrow coastal plain supports villages, gardens, and coconut groves. Coral reefs fringe portions of the coastline, and surrounding waters support subsistence fishing. The climate is equatorial maritime — hot, humid, and wet year-round.

climate_and_global_impact.content: Manam's eruptions have not produced measurable global climate effects. Even VEI 4 events inject material primarily into the upper troposphere rather than the stratosphere at tropical latitudes (where the tropopause is ~17 km), limiting atmospheric residence time and climate forcing. However, Manam is a significant contributor to the regional sulfur budget of the southwestern Pacific troposphere, with persistent SO2 emissions detectable by satellite during active phases. Manam's ash clouds affect regional aviation, particularly routes between Australia, Southeast Asia, and Pacific Island nations, monitored by the Darwin VAAC.

cultural_significance.content:
Manam holds profound cultural significance for its indigenous Manam people, Austronesian speakers with centuries of continuous habitation. The volcanic soils support exceptionally productive gardens, and surrounding waters provide rich fishing — sustaining settlement despite obvious danger. Traditional culture includes oral histories of past eruptions, communal decision-making about seeking safety, and spiritual relationships with the volcano.

The repeated evacuations since 2004 have become a subject of international humanitarian attention and academic study. Researchers in disaster risk reduction, forced displacement, and volcanology have documented Manam as a case study in the complex social, cultural, and political challenges of volcanic risk management in developing nations. The islanders' persistent return despite government warnings speaks to the depth of cultural attachment to ancestral land and the inadequacy of alternatives.

visiting_and_tourism.content: Manam is not a tourist destination. The island is an active volcanic hazard zone with no tourism infrastructure, and access is discouraged during elevated activity. Reaching Manam requires a boat from Bogia (1-2 hours), with no scheduled service. There are no hotels, guesthouses, or trails. For experienced volcanologists and adventure travelers, Manam offers a dramatic volcanic landscape, but visiting requires coordination with local communities, awareness of current activity via RVO bulletins, and complete self-sufficiency. Volcanic hazards are real and immediate — pyroclastic flows can occur with little warning. Anyone considering a visit should monitor RVO advisories and consult local authorities.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Manam is part of the Bismarck Volcanic Arc, one of the most active chains in the southwestern Pacific. Other notable volcanoes in Papua New Guinea include Ulawun (2,334 m), designated a UN Decade Volcano for its hazard potential; Rabaul caldera, which devastated the town of Rabaul in 1994; Langila, another frequently active volcano on New Britain; and Karkar, a large island volcano similar to Manam located approximately 200 km to the southeast. Papua New Guinea has 39 Holocene volcanoes, making it among the most volcanically active nations on Earth. The concentration of active volcanoes combined with limited monitoring resources and large populations on volcanic slopes creates one of the highest volcanic risk landscapes in the world.

etymology.content: The name 'Manam' is of indigenous Austronesian origin, used by the Manam people who have inhabited the island for centuries. The name refers to both the island and the volcano, which are synonymous in local usage. Early European charts used variant spellings, but 'Manam' has been standard since systematic mapping in the late 19th century. In local languages of the Madang Province coast, the island has been known by this name since well before European contact.

facts: Manam has produced four VEI 4 eruptions since 1919 — more than most volcanoes produce in centuries — making it one of the most violently active volcanoes in the southwestern Pacific.
The entire population of Manam Island — approximately 10,000 people — has been evacuated at least three times since 2004, yet most islanders have returned each time.
Manam's four radial valleys channel pyroclastic flows from the summit directly to the coast in minutes, creating a lethal funnel effect that leaves coastal villages in the direct firing line.
The volcano's total height from the seafloor is approximately 4,000 m — more than double its above-water elevation of 1,807 m — making it a massive submarine mountain.
In the 1996 eruption, pyroclastic flows killed 13 people who had no time to flee because the flows traveled from summit to coast faster than any warning system could operate.
Manam has erupted 46 times since 1616, averaging roughly one eruption every 8-9 years, though activity has been nearly continuous since the mid-20th century.
The 2004 evacuation created a displacement crisis lasting years, with evacuees in mainland camps facing inadequate shelter, food shortages, and social tension with host communities.
Both of Manam's summit craters — the Main (northern) and Southern — are active, though the Southern crater has been the dominant eruptive vent for the past century.
Five satellite volcanic cones near Manam's shoreline represent secondary vents, showing that eruptions have occurred at multiple points around the island throughout its history.
Manam's persistent SO2 emissions are regularly detected by satellite instruments, making it one of the most visible volcanic degassing sources in the western Pacific.
Papua New Guinea has 39 Holocene volcanoes — one of the highest concentrations of active volcanoes of any nation — and Manam is among the most dangerous.
The Manam people have inhabited the island for centuries despite its volcanic activity, sustained by exceptionally fertile volcanic soils and rich surrounding fisheries.

faqs.question: Is Manam Volcano currently erupting?
faqs.answer: Yes, Manam has been in a state of semi-continuous eruption since 2018. Current activity includes Strombolian explosions, ash venting, and intermittent lava flows from the Southern crater. Occasional larger explosions produce ash columns reaching 5,000-10,000 m altitude. The volcano has produced three separate VEI 4 eruptions in the 21st century alone (2004, 2014, 2018). It is monitored by the Rabaul Volcanological Observatory and the Darwin Volcanic Ash Advisory Centre tracks its ash emissions for aviation safety.

faqs.question: Where is Manam Volcano?
faqs.answer: Manam is a volcanic island in the Bismarck Sea, located 13 km off the northern coast of mainland Papua New Guinea in Madang Province. The island lies at approximately 4.08 degrees South, 145.04 degrees East. The nearest mainland town is Bogia, accessible by boat in 1-2 hours. Manam is part of the Bismarck Volcanic Arc, a chain of active volcanoes in the southwestern Pacific generated by the subduction of the Solomon Sea Plate beneath the Bismarck Plate.

faqs.question: How many people live on Manam Island?
faqs.answer: Approximately 10,000 people live on Manam Island, concentrated in villages along the narrow coastal lowlands. The population is indigenous Manam people, Austronesian speakers who have inhabited the island for centuries. The population has been evacuated entirely on at least three occasions since 2004 due to major eruptions, but most residents have returned each time due to deep cultural attachment to their ancestral homeland and the lack of viable permanent resettlement options on the mainland. The population's continued residence on one of the world's most active volcanic islands is a major humanitarian concern.

faqs.question: Why is Manam so dangerous?
faqs.answer: Manam is dangerous due to a combination of high eruption frequency, violent eruption style, and direct population exposure. The volcano has produced four VEI 4 eruptions since 1919 and erupts roughly every 8-9 years. Its four radial valleys channel pyroclastic flows from the summit directly to the coast in minutes — far too fast for evacuation. Approximately 10,000 people live in coastal villages at the base of these valleys, directly in the path of volcanic flows. The 1996 eruption killed 13 people because flows reached the coast before anyone could flee. Monitoring capabilities are limited compared to volcanoes in developed nations.

faqs.question: Has Manam been evacuated before?
faqs.answer: Yes, Manam's entire population has been evacuated multiple times. The first complete evacuation occurred in 2004 when a VEI 4 eruption forced approximately 10,000 people to relocate to mainland camps near Bogia. Further evacuations occurred during the 2014 and 2018 eruptions. Each evacuation has followed a similar pattern: initial relocation to temporary mainland camps, deteriorating conditions in the camps, gradual return of islanders to Manam over months to years, and eventual re-eruption requiring another evacuation. The Manam displacement situation is considered one of the most challenging volcano-related humanitarian crises in the Pacific.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Manam?
faqs.answer: Manam is a stratovolcano (composite volcano) built primarily from basaltic to basaltic-andesitic lava flows and pyroclastic deposits. It forms a roughly circular island approximately 10 km in diameter, with a total edifice height of approximately 4,000 m from the seafloor (1,807 m above sea level). The volcano has two active summit craters and four distinctive radial valleys that channel eruptive products to the coast. Its eruption style ranges from persistent low-level Strombolian activity to violent VEI 4 paroxysms that generate pyroclastic flows, heavy tephra fall, and lava flows reaching the sea.

faqs.question: How tall is Manam Volcano?
faqs.answer: Manam rises to 1,807 m (5,928 ft) above sea level. However, the total height of the volcanic edifice from the surrounding seafloor is approximately 4,000 m (13,100 ft), as the island is the summit of a much larger submarine mountain. Above water, the volcano presents a steep, conical profile divided into quadrants by four large radial valleys. For comparison among Papua New Guinea's volcanoes, Ulawun on New Britain is taller at 2,334 m (7,657 ft), but Manam's combination of height, isolation, and eruption frequency makes it distinctive.

faqs.question: When was Manam's worst eruption?
faqs.answer: Manam's most destructive modern eruption occurred in October-November 2004, when VEI 4 explosions sent pyroclastic flows down the southeast and southwest valleys to the coast, killing at least 5 people and destroying coastal villages. The eruption forced the first-ever complete evacuation of all approximately 10,000 island residents. However, the 1996 eruption, while less explosive overall, was arguably more lethal per capita — 13 people were killed by pyroclastic flows that reached the coast before any evacuation was possible. The 1919 VEI 4 eruption was the first major documented paroxysm.
